Executive Summary

1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System and the Aqueous Ammonia Storage System.  The facility?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.
2.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.
Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored at the site. The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity to 85% of the fill capacity for both covered processes. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 243,100 pounds.
Aqua ammonia (20% of ammonia by weight) is stored in eight above ground tanks at the site. The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 477,000 gallons of solution. The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqua ammonia, based on 20% active ingredient by weight, is 734,580 pounds. 
 
3.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and one worst case has been defined for the Aqueous Ammonia Storage.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  
Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and one alternative case has been defined for the Aqu

eous Ammonia Storage.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation  
Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an anhydrous or aqueous ammonia release.  The facility utilizes a pressure relief valve, manual shutoffs, and emergency shutdown systems.  The facility also only stores anhydrous ammonia during a brief period of the year when conversion is taking place.  During most of the year, there is no anhydrous ammonia onsite. 
 
4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.

7.    FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE
The use of flammable materials at the facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 
8.    FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE
The use of flammable materials at the facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
9.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency the facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220 is in place.
10.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 2009 PHA Report.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.
